newsitem.title: CANADA: Imperial Oil Q1 profit down after '96 gain.
newsitem.headline: Imperial Oil Q1 profit down after '96 gain.

text.p: Imperial Oil Ltd. -- Canada's biggest energy company -- Friday reported lower first-quarter net earnings vs. a year earlier when it posted a major gain from a tax refund.

Excluding the 1996 gain, Imperial's per share profit in this year's first quarter rose by 53 percent, driven by strong oil and natural gas prices, increased crude production and a major reduction in shares outstanding.

Toronto-based Imperial, 69.6 percent-owned by U.S.-based Exxon Corp. said earnings in the first quarter were C$191 million ($138 million) or C$1.21 (87 cents) a share, down from C$374 million ($269 million) or C$1.99 ($1.43) a share in the same period a year earlier.
Without the gain of C$250 million ($180 million), earnings in last year's first quarter would have been C$149 million ($107 million) or C79 cents (57 cents) a share.
Imperial is Canada's largest producer of oil and natural gas and operates the country's most extensive refining and service station network under the Esso banner.
"The company had a strong first quarter," Imperial Chief Executive Bob Peterson said in a statement. "Crude oil prices and volumes were up and downstream markets continued to improve."

The company said crude oil production rose to 271,000 barrels a day from 255,000 in the same period last year with much of the increase coming from its expanding Cold Lake heavy oil project in northeast Alberta.
Its strong average price for crude oil sales in the first quarter of 1997 also helped earnings. Imperial fetched an average C$26.76 ($19.27) a barrel, up from C$23.31 ($16.78) last year, it said.
Natural gas sales dropped to 376 million cubic feet a day from 437 million in 1996.

Last year, Imperial bought back C$1.4 billion ($1 billion) of its shares in a tender auction, which helped to bolster earnings per share and drained what was once a huge cash reserve, the company said.
